D&D's flexibility is easily sold when one can explain how the game can be as silly or as gritty, as wholesome or as degenerate, as fast-paced-OP or as difficult and grindy, as political or apolitical as the group decides. Key phrase being, "as the GROUP decides". Don't ever forget that not playing D&D at all is far better than a bad game of D&D. Know your group, know the boundaries, and you'll have a good time if you fit into the picture.

i don't really know what i'm doing but i'm running a 'campaign zero'. super simple plot:  you wake up locked in a dungeon with a hazey memory of what happened, you think that if you find out how you got trapped and who did it, you might be able to escape.   first part: you're chained up with a bunch of stuff to use (i just don't feel like listing them) and when you get out of the chains however a strange man named Daryl H. Roberts, an elderly man with a raspy voice who advocates drinking and gambling to children comes into the room, suspiciously right after you got out of the chains, and offers to help you escape the dungeon  second part: you end up in a hallway with 4 doors, three that lie, and one that tells the truth.   third part: once you guys get through the truth door you're met with you're first option, you could A, go through a tunnel full of skittsh bats that can and will try to attack you if spotted, B, use an object to try and break down a shut door using what you gathered in the begining of the campain, or C, and probably the most dangerous, listen to daryl and idk yet  thats all i got so far

My first terrible experience is when I was at new day group home we could play DND and so we had the DM mason and my friend Justin and me, i was Batman (ig) and Justin he likes venom and for whatever reason everybody just likes to make it hard to play as superheroes in DND anyways Justin had to have two character sheets for both venom and eddie wich sounds great but that means if venom in general takes damage eddie also has to take damage and with two character sheets that is alot of work for him, my second experience was at school in DND club i wanted to be goku, ofcourse i couldn't turn super Saiyan or anything so I'd basically be Db Goku before Z and that would be the munk build or whatever and when first building it i watched a video for the stats but there was this one girl in our hangout group who was like "nope you gotta role the dice" wich sucked, and before it actually got to anyone playing it was mostly just the other nerds sitting and talking, i knew i should've signed up for band practice but nope i just had to do DND class like my friend brandon so moral of the story don't try anything different just be what they have in dnd and also don't get into it just because your friend did, me personally i find this very boring it sounds good on paper but when executed not so much however it's not bad bad like honestly playing for hours on end as long as everyone has the time and gets along sounds fun but it's not really for everyone either but for those of you who do play and like it i hope that you guy's have fun bye now

my first dnd campaign i was a fighter, and my sister was a chaotic wizard named dixy normus and i was bigi shelves and we wanted to find shack, the biggest man in the world(i wont explain why we wanted to find him, trust me you dont want to know) and there was a guy that knew where he was going to be, he had ginger hair(important) and he said 3 gold for answers, we took the deal then we suspected he was a noble based on his clothes, we were right and the man was a noble, anyway shack was a friend of his father(bad father) WHO WAS A KING, a king of a place called fizz, that really liked orange, we knew were shack was going, a wizzard tower but he didnt give us directions, i try to intimidate him and i kinda forgot what happened during this bit i grabbed him, i was gonna choke him till his party came in, then i softened the hold on the neck, my sister the ine being really charismatic negotiated with em and said they will accompany with this search of shack, my favorite part was when my sister, being a chaotic wizzard decided it was time to see peoples dream, this was really simplified dnd so our dm, my cousin said roll a d20 she absolutely killed it and decided to go in one of our party members dreams and my cousin gave us a choice, his crush or backstory, we chose crush of course, and he was gay, he liked the party leader newt, newt was doing same ritual(this was real except for the love part, youâ€™ll see) so bassicaly they go to the princes room and, do well, stuff in the room luckily they didnt describe it in much detail and since it was the dreamworld we could technically do anything, so i thought it would be funny to put newt, the more girly man in a maid dress.. they stopped a little shocked, but they all were okay with it snd continued, we left that dream amd went to newts dream, this isnt as bad as his dream so were good, gladion the person that likes newt, (newt like gladion too) had a dream about gladion saving newt from falling, suddenly we were playing matchmaker we really wanted them to get together and we sucessfly did it, we still got to the tower and did that, oh yeah, she left me in that dream after the falling one, the really weird one, my character just ran nit wanting to see this.(sorry my spelling was bad in this, really tired rn)

I actually used this as a base for my own D&D oneshot (by which I mean I directly copied a bunch of it and then just tweaked the rest to suit my needs). One of my best tweaks though led to my favourite player freakout. The villain both here and in my campaign is (most likely) a warlock with a fae patron. I gave my warlock a fun little spell called Blink. Roll a d20 and if you get 11 or higher, you disappear to a different plane of existance. At the start of your next turn, you reappear, do your attack, roll to vanish, and disappear again. You can do this for ten rounds of combat per spell slot. One of my players spent two minutes swearing at me when he realized what I did.

Storytime of our DND meet last week: There was a tsunami headed for the village town we were in, and our Paladin could only teleport a few people, so he gave an invincible bubble to our rat sorcer to float in (which we dubbed "the hamster ball"), and as he floated around he found an old man. Trying to assist him, he rolled a nat 1 with a -1 modifier, meaning he essentially had a 0. He failed so hard he accidentally summoned the god of Mercy, Life, and Light, and became a paladin. Im a cleric, and me and our other Paladin are apart of the death order, so hearing this was absolutely hilarious, especially since we also have a Tiefling Samurai who is a literal demon (we were laughing on the other side of the table the whole time)

D&D adventures: I was in a campaign with 5 of my friends, 4 players 1 dm. We are fighting against big bugs, and i decide "Its the perfect time to use an aoe spell" I could hit 4 of the main enemies with it... but one of my friend would be hit aswell so i ask him to say how much hp he has. After he refuses to tell me for the 4th consecutive time i just use it, I kill all 4 enemies and the dm asks me "How do you want them to die?" And my friend in question that refused to tell me his hp says "You can also describe how i die because i f-ing got destroyed" The dm asks how much hp had before the attack, my friend tells him, he leaves the call, after 10 minutes he returns and says "Lets just say he dodged last second" We all agreed. ğŸ’€ (he survived at 1 hp, trust)

Omg I love the vox machina reference
I still remember my first session along with my friends. Our DM, a good friend, had been playing for years, yet us four had never even touched a D20 before. In our first session, in the beginning it was a bit awkward as we didn't know what to do. Our DM had put together the most simple mission she could think off, rescuing a local town's mayor from goblins. In the fight with the goblins is where our eyes opened. My friend, who played a bard dwarf, asked if he could jump off our wagon, use his shield as a skateboard to slam ontop of one of the goblins and then jam his flute down it's throat. We all was like "that would never work, that's crazy haha", but our DM went "Ye. Roll [...]" And he succeeded in doing it all, effectively killing the goblin. THAT was the moment we realised.. we can do anything? And since then we've been utter chaos gremlins and our DM wouldn't wish it any other way.
That was VILE

00:30 well, It's kinda...lame. This kind of story is kinda meme.  Just answer me this: - Did ever your group barbarian fight against Hag goons...WITH a Hag? I mean, as a weapon. Barbarian in my group just killed one goon and then ran right to the Hag! Grappled her! And beat the s**t out the other goon. This son of the gun just kept winning grapple rolls. - Same Barbarian. He wanted to intimidate a bandit. Take of his belt...and see to me what "I want to use animal handling"... We laughed a bit and I (with my big stupid mouth) sed "If you roll nat20"... You understand where it goes, right? About half of hour I was like "DM.exe stopped working" while we laughed our lungs off. So...I did the thing what every respectful DM...must do. I say he would pass if he rolls nat20...and...He did roll a nat20. So...the bandit just opened new horizons of his personality. -

After having a glass of warm milk and doing about twenty minutes of stretches before going to bed, I usually have no problems sleeping until morning. Just like a baby, I wake up without any fatigue or stress in the morning. I was told there were no issues at my last check-up. I'm trying to explain that I'm a person who wishes to live a very quiet life. I take care not to trouble myself with any enemies, like winning and losing, that would cause me to lose sleep at night. I hate riddles in D&D games.  The riddles should be for the characters, not the players.  So, the actual content of the riddle shouldn't matter, the characters should have a chance to use their lore, knowledge, wisdom, or intelligence.  There is no reason why I can't have a character that knows more or less than I do.

One of my favorite experiences was about a goat named Gertrude..  So my party and I were fighting some cursed scarecrows for a town outside of our city. We were using a goat as bait for the scarecrows and after, I decided it would be a great idea to feed this dark magical hay to this goat. Then she developed a psychic scream along with bright red pupils. It was amazing and she became my familiar and she would fight in battles with us. HOWEVER- last session it was discovered by our newest party member, Remus, that Gertrude was in fact possessed by a demon. Apparently, I opened a portal to the underworld of sorts and when I fed Gertrude the cursed hay. It came through and possessed my beloved goat. ALSO- apparently I UNKNOWINGLY signed a contract, the contents I do not know- but if I die before the contract is up he will take my soul and I will forever amuse him in the underworld. However- another plot twist. My in-game character, Faelyn, knows none of this because the demon inside Gertrude threatened Remus if he told anyone. So only Remus, the newest member, knows that my beloved goat is actually a demon who I signed some sort of contract with.   THEN we stumble across a seerer who tells me BEWARE THE DARK ONE and ONLY YOU CAN SAVE THEM. Then he promptly passed out and we put him in an invisible cage until we were done with what we were doing..  That was our last session and now I will not no more until sometime next month. ğŸ˜­  Update- her mouth is now an abyss and she drains life from those she bitesâ€¦ also she diedâ€¦  But we did a dark ritual with an itty bitty human sacrifice so sheâ€™s back ğŸ™ƒ

I remember my first time playing D&D. I played as an Ogre Warlock, (running off of Goliath rules for the race) who was a Chef that.. Well, let's say he's so incompetent at cooking, that it somehow made Gordon Ramsay himself omniscient, and uses his ire to fuel his spells. I then went on to manage to pocket an entire dead horse into a satchel, widen a small crack in the wall by just attempting to squeeze through it, and apparently, climb in through a goblin's toilet, into the boss room, circumventing the entire dungeon that was intended for us to slog through, and proceed to not only terrify everything in the room, but give two goblins food poisoning so hard, they died.  God, I miss that group. This game is wild when the DM is able to handle the sheer chaos. But it's equally as capable of creating such fantastic and compelling stories. It's fun to just turn your session into a hodgepodge of whatever you feel like, but when you get into the roleplaying aspect, look to make it one hell of a story, it's just the best.  ...Although I have to say, playing your characters with cartoon physics is also pretty funny, and you should try it with a DM that's willing and able to put up with that crap at least once.

A Tiefling who's life is literally in shambles with nothing to live for signs a pact with an eldritch being to work as a "field tech" for an office-based corporation. He was a Warlock, his Patron was literally just "The Company" but he was flavored to have time powers, and beyond his high charisma he was just a normal dude reliving the same scenarios over and over again until he got an outcome he could work with. One of my favorite supporting NPCs was "Ben, the Accountant" who literally was like tier 2 support for my character.

Shout out to Alpharad for playing a normal guy. Players need to be more willing to do this. If you are the normal person in your party (not necessarily human but human adjacent. Elf, dwarf, half orc, gnome, etc.), roleplay getting a haircut, or a tattoo, or whatever their scaly/furry/feathered/metal freak can't do. Be like "Ya, I can enjoy simple pleasures in a fantasy setting. I'm not useless when we're in town!"
D&D sure is a good way to learn social interaction and interesting creatures. Made me realize that we're all similar in a way where we are different and we should all do good to each other and the world. Strange but yeah, that's what I thought of my experience.

But Is Dungeons And Dragons A Board Game or A Mobile Game â“â“â“
I was so happy when I saw this because my dad loves d&d
I find it interesting how narratively, there are generally two different types of dnd games. The first is like this one, a bit more chaotic and focused more on having a bit of a goofier plot and are typically shorter adventures or one offs. The other type is more focused on weaving a rich narrative that really leaves you immersed, shenanigans can be involved (It is dnd after all) but these are in general a bit more serious, critical role being a prime example. A good middle ground is the adventure zone, a longer campaign with some serious and very plot heavy moments, and other times it being a bit more focused on the antics of both the players and the dm. Both can be really fun and some prefer one over the other while others like mixing it up a bit more. As a dnd veteran this is just an observation that I have made by talking to other groups of players over a long period of time and hopefully this does not somehow begin a war in the replies if there are any.

1:39 My name is Yoshikage Kira. I'm 33 years old. My house is in the northeast section of Morioh, where all the villas are, and I am not married. I work as an employee for the Kame Yu department stores, and I get home every day by 8 PM at the latest. I don't smoke, but I occasionally drink. I'm in bed by 11 PM, and make sure I get eight hours of sleep, no matter what. After having a glass of warm milk and doing about twenty minutes of stretches before going to bed, I usually have no problems sleeping until morning. Just like a baby, I wake up without any fatigue or stress in the morning. I was told there were no issues at my last check-up. I'm trying to explain that I'm a person who wishes to live a very quiet life. I take care not to trouble myself with any enemies, like winning and losing, that would cause me to lose sleep at night. That is how I deal with society, and I know that is what brings me happiness. Although, if I were to fight I wouldn't lose to anyone.

Story time. So in the very first Dnd session me and my group did, we were in a swamp. There was boat that was taking us all across to the other side. You see, the boat was powered by a magical orb, but if it used to much juice; it would explode. Long story short, there was a Kraken hiding in the swamp, and it was attracted to the glowing orb, aka our moter. In an attempt to get the Kraken to leave us alone, Our Water Genasi picked up the orb with her hand and threw it into the water. What we didn't know was the orb would cause radiation to spread up her arm as she picked up the orb.  So she had to either cut her arm off, or die on the very first session. She chose to cut her arm off, so now our party nicknamed her 'Stumpy.'

1:39 My name is Yoshikage Kira. I'm 33 years old. My house is in the northeast section of Morioh, where all the villas are, and I am not married. I work as an employee for the Kame Yu department stores, and I get home every day by 8 PM at the latest. I don't smoke, but I occasionally drink. I'm in bed by 11 PM, and make sure I get eight hours of sleep, no matter what. After having a glass of warm milk and doing about twenty minutes of stretches before going to bed, I usually have no problems sleeping until morning. Just like a baby, I wake up without any fatigue or stress in the morning. I was told there were no issues at my last check-up. I'm trying to explain that I'm a person who wishes to live a very quiet life. I take care not to trouble myself with any enemies, like winning and losing, that would cause me to lose sleep at night. That is how I deal with society, and I know that is what brings me happiness. Although, if I were to fight I wouldn't lose to anyone.

D&d is amazing
I'll never forget the time my WoD ST (Storyteller, same thing as GM/DM) ran a college student campaign with mixed books. Technically, you're supposed to stick to one book at a time, because they're definitely not balanced against each other, but who *doesn't* want a game with vampires, werewolves, hunters, mages, and all the other mystical beings in play? I chose to make a shifter, specifically a were-coyote (Nuwisha) named Ezekiel Wulfric. Nuwisha are capricious, mysterious, and always looking for fun shenanigans, and what they trade in raw power compared to werewolves, they make up for in all sorts of gimmicky but useful abilities (lockpicking talent, being capable of literal double-speak where one person hears you say one thing while anyone else hears something different, there are even some later abilities like Looney Tunes style "if I don't look down, gravity doesn't work on me"). In the course of a single session, before anyone knew better, Ezekiel was left unsupervised. He decided to go prowling around the campus, and went undercover in full coyote form. He was abruptly kidnapped by one of a group of students who had mostly already decided they were our rivals...but he happened to be caught by the only girl of their group (whose name I forget), who was not The Smart One. She saw doggy, and she decided to take the doggy since there wasn't a collar. Zeke spent the next hour or so being cleaned up, with a ridiculous number of bows tied into his fur, to the disdain of one of the other rival students. Overhearing that other student talk about his plans to do something about 'the random stray dog' while the girl was snuggled up in bed with him, Zeke waited until she was asleep, carefully escaped by unlocking the window and going outside, and quickly returning to his own dorm room. Surprisingly, everyone else was *still* busy elsewhere, so he decided to change back to normal human form and sit on the couch, pretending he did absolutely nothing in abject defiance of the obvious array of ribbons in his hair.  My ST both loves and resents my good fortune in that series of events, because it's a fun story where a dozen things could have gone wrong, and instead "Ezekiel, what did you do?" "Me? I didn't do anything." "Where'd the ribbons come from?" "Oh, those were a gift from [that girl]."

im just gonna dump a story here:  So we were level 3, on our way to kill a necromancer, we were stopped by an owl bear, 2 of us were dealing damage, the other was trying to get a hold of it by getting on top of it, and the cleric was trying and failing to tame it.  Then, out of nowhere, the cleric started to heal the damn thing, and the tables were completely turned, i was on 1 hp (mage) and our rogue was on 3, i needed this to end, so i shot a magic missile at our cleric, nearly killing him  All the while our fighter. OUR FIGHTER was trying to get its attention, after we barely made our way out of this encounter, we finally started to move again, but there was still more.  We arrived at a dungeon (cant remember the name) and our rogue decided to investigate, he then tried to offer up the rest of the party to said necromancer to save his skin, which almost resulted in him getting zombified.  Then, our cleric decides he wants to heal the zombies, but cure wounds harms them, so he uses his warhammer instead, and after all that, we finally won.

I was a light-foot halfling bard in my dnd group last year, and the scene I remember most vividly was the one that ended the current storyline. [We had been captured by the old mages son (a powerful wizard who I may or may not have seduced and inevitably fallen in love with) and were in the midst of fighting our way out.]  Tw: blood, death, violence to a moderate amount but it's DND so like what's a good last session without a battle to end it? The wizard, Marthalamule(idk if I spelled that right but idrc) had dozens of soldiers fighting me and my party, composed of a robot, an orc, a lost princess with magic hands, and a random rabbit. We had stolen weapons, and as we were fighting our way out, I saw him. Mathalamule. I had singled him out deliberately, and he smirked. "You were just so easy to fool, little halfling." H said smugly. He walked over and looked down on me.  "Oh, was I now? Last I checked it was you who let me into your home, and into your-"  He interrupted me with a scowl. "Last I checked, I have YOU cornered. A fight your party cant win, and you and your petty guild of thieves cant stop it. Zero is DEAD, and YOU are the one thing standing in my way from taking over the one piece I need to rule the world."  I scoffed. "And you think I dont have another person waiting to take over? You think they would ever, EVER listen to you?" I spat. "Come on, i know you're pretty, but you really should think more." I smiled despite what was going on, and I saw a flash of something like guilt in his eyes. I cast charm person(nat 20 + 5 charisma), and watched his face cloud over. He fumbled for words. I beckoned him down, and he got on his knees to be on my level.  "It doesn't have to be this way."  He said, emotion burning in his gaze. "Tell them to stop fighting, and I will take you to the top of the world with me. You and I can do this together." I sighed, knowing knew he cared for me before this; all it did was amplify the clouding of his senses.  "It did. And it has to end here." I said softly. Tears welled in my eyes as I hugged him. He embraced it gently, hugging me back with a loving expression. The fight around us began to slow, and my party members watched me in shock. I let go and cupped my hand around one of his checks, cradling his face and leaning to him as if I were to kiss him. His eyes closed, and I silently brought the dagger I had hidden in my cloak to his throat, slitting it as our lips almost touched. His face fell back, a look of shame, despair, betrayal, and knowledge crossing his face for nothing more than a second as he collapsed, dead. Covered in his blood and my own tears, I wept for him. The soldiers seemed to scatter like ants away, and my party stood silently as I sobbed. ~{And that was when our last session ended}~ I genuinely cried at this even though him dying was my decision and my idea but this stuck out because it was so dramatic (welcome to highschool DND people ğŸ¥²)

Cast us a lightsource" (Proceeds to summon the sun inside a large cave dungeon... everything takes fire damage) 2: "We're out of catapult ammo and the evil wizard is gloating and preparing to leave" (looks at dead Golem teammate) "He said to always be practical for everything" (Nat 20 catapults the Golem's body at the wizard and kills him... I guess I'm not alone with this situation. I never had any interest in playing D&D growing up, and didn't care for it at all. That is, until one of my work friends recently invited me to join a campaign along with a few others. We've only done a few sessions so far, but it's been fun. My character is a Kashrishi (a rhino-person) who is an earth kineticist (basically an earthbender) and an aspiring chef.  For anyone interested, our initial campaign was being hired by our DM's character to search for a highly toxic plant in order to use it to make a type of cure-all potion. Our first main encounter was a sorcerer and his garden of walking pitcher plants. Then after running into and subsequently befriending a wild owlbear (mainly through offering it food), we ran into a traveling demonic circus. Sure they appear a bit shifty, sure some of them have non-demon body parts sewed onto them, and sure they seem to have an ill-known bounty hunter among their ranks, but they're not outwardly antagonistic. So we interact with them for a while, until a scream is heard. We find that the scream came from a boy who was attacked by a monster with 10 heads and 20 arms. After treating the boy's wounds, we learn that the circus has been dealing with this "unkillable demon" for at least 10 years, probably closer to 18. It's said to be unkillable because it can only be killed in the dimensional plane it originated from, from which it was banished long ago. That being said, our party decides to hunt it in order to at least subdue it. We set out to the surrounding forest it fled to, and eventually encounter the demon that (according to the DM) closely resembles a false hydra. After a tough battle, I ended up dealing the final blow, somehow with a critical hit (beginner's luck, I'm sure). For the finisher, I slammed my hands into the ground, creating several 'precipice blades' that sliced off the demon's remaining heads and skewered the body. Then I commanded the stone to form around the body, acting like a prison, hoping that it would increase the amount of time it stays down. Afterwards, the circus thanks us for dealing with the demon, they're promised to be a recurring ally, and they give us directions to the next town.   Long story short, I definitely see why D&D can be very enjoyable now, and I'll be eagerly waiting for the next session.

1:51   My name is Yoshikage Kira. I'm 33 years old. My house is in the northeast section of Morioh, where all the villas are, and I am not married. I work as an employee for the Kame Yu department stores, and I get home every day by 8 PM at the latest. I don't smoke, but I occasionally drink. I'm in bed by 11 PM, and make sure I get eight hours of sleep, no matter what. After having a glass of warm milk and doing about twenty minutes of stretches before going to bed, I usually have no problems sleeping until morning. Just like a baby, I wake up without any fatigue or stress in the morning. I was told there were no issues at my last check-up. I'm trying to explain that I'm a person who wishes to live a very quiet life. I take care not to trouble myself with any enemies, like winning and losing, that would cause me to lose sleep at night. That is how I deal with society, and I know that is what brings me happiness. Although, if I were to fight I wouldn't lose to anyone.

I've only played one game of dnd. The best part was when we got to the boss room where we were supposed to fight a dimension shifting bee thaf fed on dreams of kidnapped humans. An orphan was kidnapped and we had gone in to rescue her. Said orphan children were not happy when instead of killing the queen we made a deal to trade her prisoners as victims in exchange for free magical artifacts. She started screaming, in response, my buddy who was playing as a 7 foot tall cow person gave her brain damage by bashing her in the head with his staff and a nat 20 crit. We could have used a sleep spell on her, knocked her out in a more gentle way, simply ignored her, straight up reality shifter her back home, gagged her, or listened to her and simply killed the queen bee. But no, the best option was to have the 7 foot tall cow monster bash her in the head.

Okay but honestly? That time loop thing has me thinking XD You've been stuck in a time loop for years now, only slight changes happening because of slightly different movements or interactions you make every time, and suddenly *two completely new people show up in the loop that you have never seen before*. Imagine going through the whole campaign and your DM is evil enough to say to you:  "You go to bed, exhausted but happy that the BBEG is defeated, excited to see where your next journey will take you. You close your eyes, drift off to sleep, and just as quickly, you slowly blink awake. You are in a familiarr room, but you haven't been here in months/years. You bolt up in your bed and frantically look around, shoving aside the curtain on the window to see whats outside. You see the same view you have seen over and over and over again for many years. You are back in your room at The Old Oak Inn, and the loop begins again". On second thought, I think I wont go the time loop route....... Oooor if I do I'll make a note to break the loop XD

Anyway, so yeah, we break out our target and then all heck breaks loose and distraction team (of which Iâ€™m on) manages to still trick the enemies right up until we have to attack to make sure our team can fully get out. And the enemies are still convinced Iâ€™m some paid bodyguard for the guy who only attacked because my charge did. Boy are they wrong! Lol it was personal (the enemies kidnapped a friend). I never intended him to be a weirdo or an idiot, but this guy is steadily growing a list of "Jack's weird and dumb ideas" as I would call it. This is a man who believed he could survive a jump from a 10 or 15 foot tall structure, at *level 2.* To my credit though, I also thought it was a good idea until my DM literally talked me off the ledge. I'm honestly surprised Jack isn't dead by now. Not because our first boss fight was unintentionally brutally hard, but because of Jack's own bad decisions.  So yeah, long story short, Jaiden is relatable to me here. Loved the video. Had many laughs. lol

One time my friend was playing a wild magic sorcerer in a campaign of my friends (wild magic means that whenever they cast a spell something weird has a chance to happen). They were unlucky enough to roll a 99 on the percentage dice (which means they get 10 more random effects), and they ended up exploding and turning into a sheep, then their skin turned blue, then they became a plant.   My friend exploded into a blue cotton plant within a minute after casting a spell. Welcome to D&D.

I DM a group in a homebrew type world, and I'm just gonna say two things.  1.) One of our party members is a Myconid Necromancer from the Shadow Wizard Mushroom Gang.  2.) One time, in the 'main village', one of the party members, (a Barbarian Tortle named Gar) decides to go talk to the local fortune teller, Zoltar. Here's how it went:  Gar: (After paying Zoltar) Zoltar, will I ever find true love?  Zoltar: (Nervous) Th-That's a tough one, buddy. You might want to see a therapist for that one.  Gar: (Agitated) Well, is there any way for me to become beautiful?  Zoltar: W-well, there is a jeweler down town who can sell you a ring that can give you makeup. B-but it's pretty cheap. You probably just want to... I don't know... Be yourself...?  Gar: I DON'T CARE!!  (Gar rushes down to the nearby jeweler's)  Gar: GIVE ME THE RING!  Jeweler: I don't know what your talking about.  (After much arguing, Gar eventually gets the ring at an immense discount with the help of his friend, and gets +2 intimidation for how bad makeup looks on a Tortle)

story time:  so, I was a wooden elf, druid and me and my party had to breaking into some place but all I remember from that thing is me turning into a black cat and just hoping around some balconies and the guards even tried to pet me but in cat fashion I just walked off. this other story happened in the same place, so the only way my party could tell it was me when I was an animal was that I had purple eyes. Anyways I was a rat in a dungeon, and I came across some other rats. Then for some reason I smelled like a human and not a rat so one of the rats was like " you smell funny...YOU'RE NIOT A RAT, YOU'RE A HUMAN". I would have died if my other druid friend didn't save me.    Another time is when me and my party can across this pack of dire wolves and only, I had the ability to talk to animals, so I can up to one wolf and started to talk to them. It went somewhat like this, "hello there" " HUH, how are you talking to me?" "Long story but can me and my party rest here for a little, we mean no harm" " alright but keep that lizard-folk away.... he looks weird". I'm glad you're having fun. First gaming experiences are special ones. I'm genuinely happy you enjoyed yourself.  That being said... and I hate to be a stick in the mud, but I'm not a fan of lolrandom DnD sessions. You can have a very silly session, but I think a lot of the fun of the game comes from having clear and consistent consequences. If a tavern can blow up from reading a speak with animal scroll... and the tavern blowing up has no consequences... It just kind of spoils the stakes of the game. If cause and effect breaks down in the game, then it's hard for me to care about what happens.

The first time I ever played DnD, a party member was a bird-person. They were investigating something, while me and the other player wanted to do the same but arrived later. When confronted with what they were doing, they said: 'Laying an egg'. Me and the other person rolled the dice to see if we would believe it, and we both did according to the dice. We then apologized (in character) to the bird-person before a door opened and we continued. I still laugh about it to this day.

So D&D is a bit if a quagmire due to who owns it, which I wont get into here.  I wanted to offer suggestion for games that people might enjoy who liked this video.  1) Pathfinder 2nd Edition. D&D but with an employee union, and a more expansive character creator.  2) Blades in the dark and the games made after it using the Forged in the Dark system. Way more focused on player agency  and feel over complexity. Main concept is like a heist movie.  3) City of Mist. Urban fantasy where you power comes from mythology and legend; such as Hades, Goldielocks, or the Pheonix.  4) Call of Cathulu. Go insane trying to solve a mystery

The thing I love about dnd is that if you tell someone a story from a session, if they play as well, theyâ€™ll almost always have a just as ridiculous tale to tell you!! And it can become a contest of whoâ€™s friends are worse.   That being said.   One time I DMd for a party consisting of a dwarf cleric, a human warlock, a human ranger and a Kalishtar paladin. The VERY FIRST session began with a horde of goblins surrounding the level 1 party in the tavern they were in. (I got tired of them trying to give them plot hooks) some rounds of combat later and the party did great rallying the villagers in the tavern in defense and held them back by making Molotovs (smart move)   however for some reason I still cannot fathom today when they came out onto the roof to throw the molotovs at the goblins trying to break in, the Kalishtar Paladin chucked a Molotov down the ladder they and another came up on. Now this wouldnâ€™t have been a issue normally, a few people could die but itâ€™s just burning some innocent civilians and maybe killing the cleric so itâ€™s chill. However I remembered I had specified before that the ladder they climbed up to reach the roof was in the same room the village kept all their alcoholâ€¦ so 99 percent of the villagers, the whole party and over 150 goblins all died in one turn.   They had backup characters. This was an average session for us.

Funny thing is, this came out the day of my friend's birthday D&D oneshot, three players were theives/assassins (me included) and the other guy was just a blind man (think Daredevil from Marvel). We were going through this magician's lair and we had to find five keys, first room was a room with a large door that had symbols on it and a shiny red button, the second room had an enemy encounter where me and one other player befriended displacer beasts (they look like panthers with six legs and two tentacle tails), the blind guy was mauled by our new friends because he killed another displacer beast and was carrying the head around like a trophy. We gather the rest of the keys and enter the room with the magician, where Theif One tries to charm the magician into giving us the item we were after, that didn't work and they got burnt with a fire spell. After a few rounds of combat, Theif two was able to steal his spellbook and tore out some random pages to cast spells and casted Freeze Time. Long story short Theif Two dealt a total of 66 damage to the magician and I was able to get the finishing blow, chopping his head off and ending the battle and apparently saving us an entire rematch agianst him (he planned to cast wish to wish fo us to return to when we first entered)

My DM once was coming up with junk items at a magic store and created an item that was essentially liquefied cotton candy where half a drop would create enough to feed the party for a full day. I bought several bottles of the stuff and I did the math on how much cotton candy I actually had, I did the math and we realized that they could be used like grenades as one bottle held enough cotton candy to explode a house from the pressure. Anyways. I could change my nose from a pink one, bottle cap, and a bird beak. If you think THIS story was crazy, then prepare to hear some of MINE! So here is the thing, I was playing in a different setting, the one with a Pyramid and you explore the pyramid. I was also a Dragonborn named â€œDracsgroâ€ (I had no name ideas so deal with it) for my first time so cool, but I was also a monk. Story 1: Me and the rest of the people were exploring like the basement of the pyramid, and then we opened a trap door and a bunch of bats came out shaping a bigger bat(?), and he killed everyone except for me. Then (in real life) I rolled a 20, which means something really good happens, and my dungeon master saw that could not explain how to fit it IN GAME! So I will just call it the â€œoverpower-no-jutsuâ€, and because of it it decreased harshly the number of bats presented. And one of my friends revived and killed itâ€¦ yaaaaaaay! Story 2: Me and the rest of the people were exploring even deeper the basement of the pyramid, and there was this place with a door in front of us and a hallway to the left. I choose to go alone on the pathway to left, and literally THE FIRST THING THAT HAPPENS WHEN I STEP IN THE HALLWAY WAS GETTING HIT BU A TRAP THAT WAS LIKE AN AXE THAT SWING HORIZONTALLY! WHAT ARE THE CHANCES OF A RANDOM HALLWAY HAVING TRAPS!!!! Any may mean while the rest of the people were fighting a bunch of skeletons and loosing badly, like everyone was dying (except of course me), and you know what I did? *[WARNING: the following strategy might be so smart that your brain will not manage how genius that was]* I PLAYED DEAD, and they left me alone, so I could stabilize my self and the rest of the party. Genius I know.

We played something similar in boy scouts, we called it makeshift D&D. Reason being was because we had no rules to what you could do and only 1 20 sided die that my friend brought. One campaign that I really liked was when we had an all out brawl just for the fun of it. I was some sort of buff guy named Darrel, my friend was a wizard yoshi that loved to eat grass, another friend was an avocado with god-like powers, my brother was kermit the dog, kermit the frog with a dog body, and my other friend was an imposter from among us. We all started hanging out and whatnot, then I accidently destroyed some of wizard yoshis grass and fighting began, I don't remember all the details of the fight but what I do remember was that wizard yoshi turned the entire world into the state of New Mexico and I was was about to snap wizard yoshis neck. At the last second, he pulled out an uno reverse card and I snapped my own neck. After the conundrum, I was exiled to another planet. Never to be seen again.

Ok, I'm a dm for a group of legit crazy people, this video reminds me of them. The barbarian killed a horse carriage guy because he had seahorses.
I've also started playing DnD this year, and it's much more fun than I ever imagined! Before starting our current campaign, my friends and I just silently agreed that we had to make characters which were extremely competent at something but simultaneously seem like weirdos at first glance. So here's our party:  -A two-meter-tall dragonborn barbarian who's noticeably dumb and is always accompanied by a bird, who's apparently his son (No, he hasn't explained that part of his lore yet) -A human bloodhunter who literally has no emotions (the player somehow makes it work), almost always covered with a white cape and mask  -A tall tabaxi ranger which behaves like a typical calm, collected human, but randomly does cat stuff (he coffs up hair balls from time to time). Also, he has adopted a worg puppy. Doesn't even have a purpose for it, he just felt like it -A 4 ft tall ratfolk who's an expert on marksmanship, for some reason? Also he has 18 INT but around 6 WIS, so he's super smart but barely retains any knowledge -A human noble who hasn't finished writing his lore yet, but has managed to give out 3 epic speeches. He convinced a whole town to fight against a tribe of goblins with an improvised speech. But we keep teasing him because not even him knows his own past -A high elf wizard who dominates the magic of the stars and may attempt to predict the future by studying the night sky. Fun stuff is: he doesn't know wether each vision is true, partially true, or completely false, nor when and where it will take place. Also he has the lowest amount of HP in the party and a single well-placed shot can take him down -And my character: a dwarven rogue who was born on a thief-guild and barely speaks dwarf because she wasn't only taught by her mother. She also probably has ADHD, and she mostly doesn't care what's happening around her because she knows she wouldn't figure it out if she wanted to. I'm planning on slowly revealing her tragic past, but for now she's just the dwarven silly woman who steals only out of survival AND spite, and I'm all for it

1:39 My name is Yoshikage Kira. I'm 33 years old. My house is in the northeast section of Morioh, where all the villas are, and I am not married. I work as an employee for the Kame Yu department stores, and I get home every day by 8 PM at the latest. I don't smoke, but I occasionally drink. I'm in bed by 11 PM, and make sure I get eight hours of sleep, no matter what. After having a glass of warm milk and doing about twenty minutes of stretches before going to bed, I usually have no problems sleeping until morning. Just like a baby, I wake up without any fatigue or stress in the morning. I was told there were no issues at my last check-up. I'm trying to explain that I'm a person who wishes to live a very quiet life. I take care not to trouble myself with any enemies, like winning and losing, that would cause me to lose sleep at night. That is how I deal with society, and I know that is what brings me happiness. Although, if I were to fight I wouldn't lose to anyone.

wait...RANBOO!?WHAT THE CRA-
A decade or two ago (let alone since inception, OOOOF), DnD was not popular at all. I'm 30, and growing up it was treated as the literal embodiment of evil. Along with Harry Potter. One of those came true... I didn't experience DnD until my mid 20's.  I am astounded at how such a simple idea of story telling and limitless creativity can still be regarded as a bad thing. Knowing that there are still kids growing up to this day, who are taught that creativity is just pure evil, terrifies and breaks me. Knowledge, open-mindedness, critical thinking...etc... It can be a real unreal forum of ideas and fun and respect.  It just makes me so giddy and sad at the same time. There are too many "parents" who punish their kids for no reason, for even just creating their own thoughts and realizing their own opinions.  slkjfl;asjdflkasjdflksdjf;askjf;laskjdf;sadkjf  Thanks for sharing Jaiden, that was super fun

One-shot was very Slime's style. Love it!
My name is Yoshikage Kira. I'm 33 years old. My house is in the northeast section of Morioh, where all the villas are, and I am not married. I work as an employee for the Kame Yu department stores, and I get home every day by 8 PM at the latest. I don't smoke, but I occasionally drink. I'm in bed by 11 PM, and make sure I get eight hours of sleep, no matter what. After having a glass of warm milk and doing about twenty minutes of stretches before going to bed, I usually have no problems sleeping until morning. Just like a baby, I wake up without any fatigue or stress in the morning. I was told there were no issues at my last check-up. I'm trying to explain that I'm a person who wishes to live a very quiet life. I take care not to trouble myself with any enemies, like winning and losing, that would cause me to lose sleep at night. The acid breath moment was hilarious   My most unhinged game moment, the beginning and end of a bitter, unscripted vendetta.  My party was traveling to an old castle when we were jumped by a group of goblins. We managed to kill all but 2. We tied one up and put a knife to the other. We were trying to get information out of him but he wasn't budging so wre had to ramp it up. We told him to pick up a rock to unalive the other that we had tied up, or be unalived himself. As he approached the tied up goblin, she woke up and realized what was happening and said "its ok, honey. Do it". We very quickly found out they were married with kids after we looted her corpse and found a childs drawing of their family. After event's unfold, he escapes and fast forward to the end of the campaign, we find out that he's teamed up with the boss of the game and is the miniboss before the main. Almost as soon as the battle starts, one of the player's throws down an anti-graviry orb and plunges his sword in the ground. In the end, qe each took ranged shots at him sending him over an edge where he falls to his death.

Tldr; that was really cool, I wrote a whole novel in that comment woops  If I were to guess everyone's builds for funsies : Jayden was a black dragonborn due to the color and acid breath, she was most likely a sorcerer, because a warlock would of ran out of spell slots and sorcerers start with daggers (such as the ones that were thrown into the ceiling's eye) also the magic thingy on her character's tongue which could be draconic bloodline and I don't think they were a wizard, as they used a lvl 2 spell which wizards do not have at level 1 unlike sorcerers  The cat was obviously a bard, I don't recall if bards start with their college already chosen at level 1.   Cat means tabaxi, however, tabaxi are typically taller than humans, that would probably mean that either they used tasha's cauldron of everything's rule of "if it sounds cool and your dm agrees then screw the predefined archetypes" which would allow for a small tabaxi (that or they were flavoured as being short with no actual impact on the rules)   Meanwhile, Paul was a human barbarian due to the great axe. If not, they were a fighter, which would be hilarious, as Larry the normal type gym leader everyday man who works 9 to 5 would absolutely be the everyday human fighter.  The DM was really good at rolling with the chaos, like that must of been quite a puzzle to figure out how to deal with groundhog day cat and M&L bros attacks. 4:16 this reminds me of my first campaign, i was a 7ft tall snow white dragonborn wizard named starkeeper, the day couldnt make it, one of my party members (also a wizard) tryed to cast ray of frost, but miss spoke and cast "ray of frog instead, so the next time i was there he tryed to cast the same "ray of frog" spell but he only wanted to sommon 1 building sized one, he rolled a 3, he casted the frog and it was the size of a basketball, a second later it was eaten by an aligator, once we killed it i ripped out some of the gators teeth and cut open a hole in the gators stomach to retrieve the frog, than I glued the gator teeth to the frog as if they were spikes, thus, starkeepers frog "Bartholomew" was born, and Bartholomew is still in my inventory today!

I did not know how much I needed this omfg
I have a story to tell of my own Our former group was of villains from various franchises for this story. I was Ganondorf, there was Kronk from Emperor's New Groove, Deathstroke, Doctor Octopus, and a couple others. We started in a cell only to be let out because I used my magic to go small and then big to open the door from the other side. We walked down the hall until we came to a door that let into a 4-door room where there was a door on each wall. the two on the sides were barred off at the moment but the one ahead of us was massive and through said door appeared a giant goblin skeleton. It could speak and it said it was the deity of the realm but had no name so it asked us for a name that could be known far and wide throughout the realm for his followers to know him as. While we were thinking up names for it, Kronk decided to suggest, " How about Squirrel?" So knowing Ganondorf's high Charisma stat I somehow rolled a Nat 20 and was able to persuade the deity to accept the name "Squirrel", he then suddenly grew wings and flew out of the open ceiling leaving us to go through the open door. On the outside I could see a squirrel jumping through the trees and laughed saying, " Welp there's our deity right now." The DM Shelby was so flabbergasted that we succeeded that we BROKE his story for the campaign. Which was hilarious since it was the shortest one ever, that's why DnD can be fun.  Now if only I could find more people to enjoy it with.

I love that everyone that plays has the one story from a campain where their character gets to be the ultimate badass.  Mine is from my first campaign. We were fighting the BBEG, which was a lich, and the pace we were fighting it was basically a circular room with a bottomless pit in the center. One side was blocked, and ot immediately used wall of force on the other side to block our party's 3 martial characters from reaching it. I was the only caster/ranged attacker as a sorcerer, so I ended up having a magical duel with this lich across the pit, with me hittong him with the highest damage spells I had to try and get him to lose concentration, couterspelling, and cannibalizing my lower level slots for sorcery points to get higher level slots back. Eventually, the DM got frustrated and cast banishment on me. He looked up, ready for me to counterspell, but forgot that banishment is concentration. So I just said, I flip him off and tell him to have fun. I was out the rest of the very short fight as the three very annoyed martial characters absolutely annihalated it. Good times.

My DM, I was a animal tamer, and during the run, I had been saving my gold up because of there was a healer in our group who knew I would go head first into battle. Well, during our run, we found a secret cave and went to explore it. One was able to find that the cave was lived in and we decided to wait for it outside. When it showed up, the idea was to jump the person and steal his weapons and armor but what really showed up was... a Dragon. Panic was on the table as we knew the plan wouldn't work when I took a chance to see if I could be friend the dragon. The role wasn't very high but I was able to get the dragon on our team by handing him over a big bag of coins and basically, easily beat the Dungeon Master who, oddly, never thought the Dragon could be won over like that.

I'm glad you enjoyed D&D. Now that you've got a taste of it I strongly suggest you try out Pathfinder, especially 2e which is very similar to D&D but some difference to give the system it's own identity. I recommend it because having played both I feel like a lot of people would probably really like Pathfinder but are often worried about trying out new systems, and also I think Pathfinder is able to make so many more cool and crazy characters with all all the options it gives you while not overwhelming you with it. It also has the advantage of not being made by a company that sent the literal *Pinkertons* to someones house over a missunderstanding. So that's always a plus.

as a dm for a few years i gotta give huge props to charlie for this. the adventure was spectacular and had a ton of hallmarks for an amazing session. the adventure was simple and each event led pretty seamlessly into one another. every PC's goals were focused towards the sessions objectives in a way that let the characters themselves almost entirely move the story, the clay puzzle was amazing as it supported the player's creativity by making each enemy BE personally hand crafted for them, by them. and every location feels unique and flush with classic tropes (polymorph, dungeons, goblins, even starting in a tavern), making it feel as d&d as possible for an intro to the game. well fucking done. also boyl and the peeler are amazing npcs, elegantly simple

I KNOW THIS ONE SHOT
I play an adorable orc. His name is Haeden and he is a druid. Due to the worlds issues in regards to orcs he is on a personal quest to make his parents proud and possibly show the world that orcs aren't that bad. For quite some time he was a quiet completely non speaking background character cause he is worried people are gonna misjudg his way of speach since he grew up in the forest in hiding. We have an elf mage who has started helping him with words and speach and who we are madly in love with although not realising yet and she has started going with him when we seperate the group. My orc is wise but has developed a temper when it comes to his elf.  We once went into a library and she asked for a book on some ancient guy. The librarian was very rude and said it's very unladylike. My boy leaned in and slammed a hand on the table. I rolled a 19 on Intimidation and have a +3 bonus so the librarian shat himself and rolled a nat 20 strength breaking the desk. Lucia (the elf) was smitten a lil and had to calm me down and I spent the rest of the session brooding over hom someone could be so rude to someone so pretty.

I rememebr one of my coolest moments in DnD. I was playing a blind paladin and we had been ambushed by a dragon. We beat it up and eventually it tryed to run away. Just as a joke, I asked if I could throw a pebble at it randomly. The DM made me roll for it, and I rolled a doble nat 20 at disadvantage.  So my blind paladin killed a fleeing dragon while throwing a pebble in a random direction at it.

This channel's content has come so far since it started out, and my God is this video a perfect example of the astounding quality of the videos on this channel lately.  This one's got it all: the storytelling is on point, Jaiden's vocal performance is compelling and vastly improved from her early works. The animation is delicately stylized and buttery-smooth - the frames pop out like panels from a comic book, especially in the climax. Look at how beautifully drawn and coloured this video is (especially at 16:12 with the atmospheric lighting effects in the background and the visual effects that call to mind some of the flashiest 80s anime series)! And to think Jaiden's first videos were almost completely in black and white!  I can't wait to see JaidenAnimations get even more slick and stylish as the quality of the content uploaded to this channel continues to make further leaps and bounds in quality. Already I am astounded by every new video that she publishes - each new upload is better than the last, whether through the wittier comedy, the more engrossing plots or the crisper, more vivid visuals. If this is the direction this channel is heading in, I have no complaints!  But now on a more personal note: Jaiden, if you're reading this, I just wanted to tell you that your videos are redefining what it means to be a creator of quality content on YouTube. You lead one of the only channels of this size that has ever undergone a successful genre shift (from storytime animation to gaming animation) not only without alienating its audience but also broadening in size and encompassing a whole new portion of the Internet. That is no easy task, I'm sure, yet you pulled it off. You've also adapted to your changing audience, while remaining completely unbothered by the status quo, so I certainly can't say you're unwilling to diversify!  I just wanted to tell you, Jaiden, that even though you don't even know who I am, and even though I've never met you in real life, that the things you do are absolutely mesmerizing. You never disappoint with your consistently high-quality and beautiful content that leaves me either smiling ear-to-ear or shedding tears - you are among the few YouTubers that can do that consistently for me. Just today, watching you retell the story of your D&D campaign made me relive my childhood and teenage memories, from back when I played Dungeons and Dragons for the first time and got hooked right from the start!  You're fucking fantastic, and I implore you not to ever let anyone tell you that you're not. For our sake - your sake, my sake, your viewers' and your supporters' sake - never let them permeate you, even when their words and their actions bite, sting, kick, scratch, cut - because we all love you. Every single one of us loves you more than you could ever know. And I'm sure your enemies wouldn't ever want to be enemies with you once they get to know just how wonderful and beautiful you are, in your mind and in your soul. Keep shining on like the brilliant star we know you are!!!

Once, I needed a new character, so I made a guy, and her backstory was that she was originally a chair, but was permanently polymorphed into a half-elf woman named Ivellios, and halfway through the campaign, she walked into an anti-magic field, causing her to turn back into a chair. Everybody else was so terrified to go into the field that our ranger had to handle the entire fight on their own, and it took almost twenty minutes to het the chair polymorphed back into Ivellios. That will always be my favorite character I've ever played.

I like this new art style
My first table top role playing experience was of a home made game of Resident Evil. The point was to test if a new rpg player could easily grasp the mechanics. We were a group of 3 (two experienced players and me) + the game master. I... added accidental chaos to the game. To say the least.  I can't remember the details of the mission, but it's resident evil : go somewhere for a mission, surprise! there are zombies everywhere, survive/escape and ideally complete the mission.  So with that mindset : we were a group of professionnaly trained soldiers going into a national reserve? that also serves as a secret lab of some sort. Out mission was to investigate the lack of communication of a few other soldiers that were sent there. We investigate an old barn, but the noise we make fighting a strange, eyeless creature with a very long thounge (it's a licker for those who know RE) attracts a swarm of zombies outside the barn. We flee to the roof. At least, we try to. But someone... Okay, I, fell down the rope we used to climb up  and fainted on impact. The noise of my failure attracted the zombie that were bashing at the barn doors. My teammates had to go back down the rope and climb up with me while fending off the swarm. I end up waking up midway through the climb and tossed a grenade down giving us a bit more time, but also... Attracting more zombies. Now stuck on the roof, we must parcour our way down by jumping down to a shed nearby. Which I ALSO fumble my dice roll, so I end up missing my jump, jumping full force on the side wall of the shed and getting knocked out cold, again. With my amazing level of discretion, I attracted the attention of the zombies and so my teammates rush down, and drag my helpless meat sack into the cover of the forest.  I wake up a few minutes later and we push through the forest until we find a clearing. We are at the edge of a small cliff when suddenly out of the forest comes 2 very sickly looking dogs. One of the dogs rammed into one of my team mate, pushing him down the cliff and the other was detected and failled his tackle.  Me and my teammate still on top of the cliff, decides to throw rocks and branches at the dogs to try and fend them off our friend who was fighting them with a knife. We were affraid of using our guns and calling the whole damned park over to us. Eventually I get sick of that useless tactic and decide to plunge knife first down the cliff. The dog I was aiming for barely dodge the attack, but in my amazing comeback of dice roll luck, I swiped at the dog with my knife and sliced his throat in one go, nearly decapitating it in the process. One dog down, one more to go, together with my teammates we defeated the other dog, but as the fight finished, we could hear numerous barking in the distance, getting closer. We ran along the cliff until we found a weird, magnetic key activated door. We had found the key in the barn earlier and so, got in, closing the door behing us.   And that, was my first ever table top rpg experience and I'll never forget how much we laughed that day.

Lmao DnD is an amazing game, I would absolutely love to hear more stories from your campaign if you continue, these characters sound like they have the makings for an incredible adventure. If you haven't already, I highly recommend checking out some of the animated DnD stories here on youtube (Dingo doodles Fool's Gold is a true Epic you don't want to miss!)   An anecdote from my first DnD campaign because Zute (Spelling?) spraying Mark in the face reminded me of this legendary moment:  We'd gotten into a couple of scrapes with Orcs before, but you could consider this out first big Boss fight as our characters, Tadeusz (mine, Lizardfolk solider) Arda (Half Orc Cleric) Slava (Dragonborn Barbarian) and Sariel (elf ranger) found themselves toe to toe with an Eye of Gruumsh named Gresh while attempting to rescue a local farmer.  We kept making low rolls and missing our attacks so Gresh wasn't really impressed with us, which was totally fine with us because he kept missing his as well, meaning we weren't super impressed with him either; Particularily after Gresh used a command spell on Arda to force her to kneel and point his weapon point blank at her face, and used a massive spell to attempt to finish her off in a single hit...And missed with a low roll.  We spent the entire rest of the fight mocking him for it, and Gresh did eventually kill Arda with a physical attack after she failed her death save rolls, but unfortunately for Gresh Arda was the only one in the party Tadeusz actually liked and she'd already beat him down pretty bad, so Tadeusz saw his friend get killed and dropped what he was doing to go finish him off with a triumphant "Where's your god now!?" that understandably got him beat within an inch of his life by Gresh's companions.   Slava and Sariel managed to hold the rest of the Orcs off, but all remaining players and orcs were one good hit from death at this point. Gresh rolled a successful death save with 1 hit point and mocked them as being next, and once again unfortunately for him Tadeusz succeeded his death save and chucked his quarterstaff at him from across the field with a high roll, instantly killing him once again and I used my bonus action to use Tadeusz's Second Wind ability so he didn't die before we finished off the orcs.   In summary, Taduesz landed the death blow on this guy *twice*, and to rub it in even more, Tadeusz is a Lizardfolk so guess what, he ate him afterwards, too. Gruumsh probably has it out for Tadeusz at this point, but at least our party had a happy Lizard

I got into D&D back when I was still in high school, with this online group that I still play in several years later. Let me tell you about one wild session from our first campaign (which ended earlier this year, the second oneâ€™s been going on for a few months). I rolled up a sorcerer with proficiencies in pretty much all the Charisma stats including performance, this will be important later.   So our party heads to the Feywild to ask the Fey Queen Titania for help getting access to the Elemental Planes, as we needed to enter each of them to find these 4 elemental stones. The Fey Queen is a bit mistrusting, so I, being newer to the group and a bit shy, chime in, â€œHey, could I try to serenade her with a rendition of Never Gonna Give You Up?â€ Everyone goes silent for a couple minutes, then the DM goes, â€œYou know what? Roll me a performance check.â€  I roll a Nat 20. The total of that roll was a 27.  The other players and the DM erupt into excited cheers as I relay this, and the DM says sheâ€™s utterly wooed by the performance, and we get the info we need.  Now you may wonder, what happened with my character and the Fey Queen? Weeeeell they ended up falling in love and marrying in a later part of the campaign, and in campaign 2, are currently happily married with their twin children set to inherit their respective mothersâ€™ titles.  In short: You wanna do batshit insane stuff you could never do IRL? You want a story where you can influence events and be who you want? Play D&D!
Now this, THIS is a campaign that I would LOVE to do

Love dnd, did a one shot with friends last night, our group consisted of a tabaxi monk (me), a tortle druid, a rock gnome thief and eladrin thief. We were doing the lightning tower. Highlights from it include my tabaxi getting to group into the tower by making a high jump and lowering a rope to forgo looking for a secret entrance. My tabaxi grabbing a shield with the towers crest on it and triggering the trap which turned him into a fried kitty. The wildfire tortle swan diving into a well with fire spirit in tow the rock gnome following suit to help get one of the lightning rods and both facing a water weird. My tabaxi, not trusting a chained wardrobe that was shaking, pulling out a torch and lighting the room on fire while the tortle's fire spirit was frolicking in the burning room and found another rod. And the tortle nearly getting impelled by one of the rods as it rapidly change sizes. There are more highlights but none appropriate to say on here, like a running joke about tortle's anatomy.

During the shady guy and Vikings fight, one of the Vikings get slaughtered by one of the shady guys.    Another one of the Vikings, overcome by sadness and rage, kills the first set of shady, dies and chops off my friends hand. She killed him.  The bartender, then gets a gun, and fires it towards me. I dodge it, but it has a boomerang effect. It gets my shoulder. After all that chaos, the bartender comes towards us, and says:  â€œYou have passedâ€ - toward me â€œYou have not.â€ - toward bestie. Paul, Paul, Paul... Never forget to make a cougar check when you are in the woods. But yeah, D&D is fun and puzzle dungeons can be very entertaining, the hard thing is to make them just difficult enough. They can easily get too hard or too easy.  Heh, I remember when I drove my players nuts in one. We had 2 experienced players and 2 new ones. This was the second session and second dungeon, they had solved everything so far (or at least survived an oopsie or 2) by carefully taking their time. This time they enters a room with an empty chest in the middle and a mirror on the wall (I already used a mirror trap in the first dungeon. When they study the room they see the chest is filled with treasure but they also see the old evil wizard who built the dungeon long ago. And here is the evil part, I suddenly out of nowhere switch to real time. They see the wizard go to the chest and pick up an item (me providing a picture, it looks expensive) and walks away with it. Everyone is confused and starts chatting but a minute later the wizards shows up again and take something else. The players are getting a bit stressed and starts trying examining things.  When the wizard comes the third time, they panic and break the mirror which sadly destroys all the rest of the treasure. They were pretty mad. :)  There are of course many other fun ways to play D&D, everything from a murder mystery to strategic warfare, romantic comedy or whatever you think is funny but puzzle dungeons have a special place in my heart. As a player you feel incredible smart when you figure out each puzzle, it might be a bit like giving a dog a treat for making a trick, but it is fun.  If you run those, don't have too many "You must solve this puzzle to proceed" though, have more "you get a treasure if you solve this" since it is easy the players get stuck otherwise and that ain't no fun. I use 3D dungeons for these kinds of things myself, but a floorplan or just some drawing works fine too.
Iâ€™ve never laughed so hard as I did during this session, and itâ€™s amazing to see it all animated :D

That was super fun.  I would love to see the actual session, and I hope you get the chance to play more soon.  Just to add to how unhinged D&D can get, I was part of a one shot last night.  We were fighting a drow that had information on our quest giver's missing brother and were supposed to "bring back alive, preferably" and a dracolich, when our druid asked our dm a simple question.  Has he ever seen a t-rex?  One high/low roll later, the rest of us were polymorphed into t-rexes.  Let's just say there wasn't much left of our enemies.  But it wasn't our fault we killed the guy.  We had an intelligence of 2.  My meek, bookish former space pirate astral elf wizard was reveling in the power.  It.  Was.  Incredible!

1:40 My name is Yoshikage Kira. I'm 33 years old. My house is in the northeast section of Morioh, where all the villas are, and I am not married. I work as an employee for the Kame Yu department stores, and I get home every day by 8 PM at the latest. I don't smoke, but I occasionally drink. I'm in bed by 11 PM, and make sure I get eight hours of sleep, no matter what. After having a glass of warm milk and doing about twenty minutes of stretches before going to bed, I usually have no problems sleeping until morning. Just like a baby, I wake up without any fatigue or stress in the morning. I was told there were no issues at my last check-up. I'm trying to explain that I'm a person who wishes to live a very quiet life. I take care not to trouble myself with any enemies, like winning and losing, that would cause me to lose sleep at night. That is how I deal with society, and I know that is what brings me happiness. Although, if I were to fight I wouldn't lose to anyone.

LARRY!
Here's a fun DnD story for those who want it I was playing it at summer camp with my Boy Scout friends.We all had our roles (unimportant however) and we were trying to get rid of a goblin infestation, our dungeon master said we found a goblin king,and said it looked like the one from the Hobbit. We didn't have many figures with us,so we used the best thing we had,a Bowser chess piece from a 15 set of Mario chess. We came up with a name until one guy came up with the best words I have ever heard... "Hobga Gobga" We all agreed it was best and used our weapons to take him down.I got the first hit of damage (which took down most of his health) with my magic javelin it glowed and returned to my hand (like loyalty on a trident in Mincraft) as I hit him in the eye.After we had defeated him he dropped a mystical artofact,his crown. They all said that I should be the one to carry it,and it gave me the ability to summon his ghost to assist us in battle once in a fortnight. And that was how I became Cornelius Featherbottom,The Hobga Gobga Slayer   P.S Yes the name is dumb,it was my first time Playing.

i was in a dnd club with a bunch of high schoolers in middle school (i was like their baby or smth idk they acted like i was their kid) and we called our DM 'Dungeon Mommy'. we almost never finished a campaign because we got distracted so often and one of the party members was always a bird of some sort. she never stopped cawing and screeching and anytime she opened her mouth, one of us would yell something like "*****, i swear to god if you're about to make another bird noise, I'll rip your throat out" or her brother would just reach across the table and shut her mouth before she did anything.  we once acted out a genuine fist fight to solve a disagreement. i had the highest charisma stat so i flirted with any enemy we came across. my character was named Po, after the teletubby (i also had the antenna). 10/10 would recommend. (also being the high schooler's favorite middle schooler and being adopted by them is a highly underrated experience, would also recommend)

I have a great moment in DnD that I like to call "The Briefcase Blunderbuss"  Long story short, we had one of our party members get into a bag of holding and hang on to the outside of the bag with one hand and his "thunder cannon" in the other while peaking it's barrel out of the bag. (a magic blunderbuss basically) and occasionally popping his head out to breathe, Shooting anything in front of us. My character held the bag in front of them when we were walking through hallways in a crypt in one of our campaigns. It was effective.

No way! I just started D&D recently  I actually made a journal/Script thingy like that. I will put it below \/    Today was the day the storm started. The beginning. I was outside with my friend, Bob. And thatâ€™s when it started to get really windy and cold. We realized a snow storm was coming up on us. So we headed over to a Tavern nearby. We were really confused since it was the middle of summer and a blizzard showed up. In the Tavern, we met two other guys, Pretzel God and Cut Turr. We were all talking about the blizzard when Cut Turr asked another guy what was happening, all he knew was that it was coming from the North. Since I have been recently training as a wizard, I cast a fireball spell on a torch to light it. That way we wouldnâ€™t freeze to death. We all went outside to look for some horses to use to see what was going on in the North. We eventually found a stable and stole the horses to cover ground a lot faster. After some time we came up on an Ice giant which was casting a spell causing the blizzard. He didnâ€™t seem like the mean kind of ice giant so Bob asked it why it was casting the spell. The giant explained that a knight had shot an arrow through his hand breaking that hands power and thus, making the blizzard. Pretzel god helped him stop the blizzard and he rewarded Pretzel god with a giant Ice mace. The problem was that the mace was twice Pretzel Godâ€™s size which meant he couldnâ€™t pick it up. Bob also tried to pick it up but still failed. But when I tried to pick it up, I used a magic spell that gave me super strength and I was able to pick it up. Later, we returned to the village and Cut Turr split up with us because he was a nice gentlemen who wanted to return his horse. When we tried to enter the village, they notice we stole their horses. I tried to convince them I didnâ€™t but they didnâ€™t believe me in the slightest. So, we stayed out of the village for some time. Thatâ€™s when I saw something unusual. It was a large well with a tower over it that went so high, you couldnâ€™t see the top. Another weird thing was that you couldnâ€™t see the bottom of the well and there wasnâ€™t any water in the well. We decided to take a risk and jump into the well. After a long fall and a weird spell that made it so we didnâ€™t die, we found ourselves in the black market that we had heard about but never seen. Me, Bob and Pretzel God decided to sell our horses. Me and Bob decided to work together to sell both our horses and then split the money. We ended up selling our horses for 50 gold each. Pretzel God forgot how much a horse costed and ended up selling his horse for 2 copper. But he did gamble a little and make a lot of money. Thatâ€™s when Bob killed someone for his stuff which I didnâ€™t think he had in him since we had been living in a cave up to that point. After that, I noticed that I still had the giant Ice mace, but I also noticed I wouldnâ€™t be able to use it, so I sold it for a whopping 51 platinum. Bob helped me sell it so I gave him 8 platinum for that. A little later, me and Bob left the black market because we had just struck it rich. Pretzel god had also struck it rich but he had other plans to stay in the black market and party all night while getting drunk. I left Bob in the town and went out of the village a little to find a nice place to build a home. Thatâ€™s when I found a nice plot of land, so I staked the claim, and started the building process. I didnâ€™t know what to build the house out of, so I went shopping for materials, sadly I went shopping hungry and all I bought was 22 tons of bread. Good thing it was crispy bread which meant it was the perfect material to build a house out of. I built a three story mansion with a pool. I felt a little lonely in my house, so I went out into the forest to find a pet. I couldnâ€™t find anything so I used my natural likeness of nature to wait for a pet. Eventually, my favorite animal came to me, a duck. Thatâ€™s when it started getting late, so I went to bed.
